[*]Find a nursing home in your area (that's generally where old people go to die)[*]Visit your local animal shelter and arrange to 'borrow' a bunch of cats and dogs for an afternoon[*]Contact the nursing home and explain your intent[*]Deliver the cats/dogs to the nursing home[*]Stand back and watch what happens
I tried it, but was unfortunately foiled at step 3 as I had absolutely no idea what the intent was.

I tried it, but was unfortunately foiled at step 3 as I had absolutely no idea what the intent was.

 
 
 The intent is to let the people in the nursing home have contact with pets.
Oh, I thought it was some kind of prank, where you "borrow" a bunch of animals and then set them loose in an old folks home.

Oh, I thought it was some kind of prank, where you "borrow" a bunch of animals and then set them loose in an old folks home.
Ah yeah, thats what I thought was implied too. We are obviously too cynical!

My partner's grandmother was in a nursing home in Pa. where they had dogs, cats, and birds living in the home as companions for the residents. This one cat was always in gram's room. It is a nice way to keep the elderly company.

Even without the nursing home bit, people really should go borrow animals from shelters. Most humane societies will let you. Most dogs and cats are there for years if not their whole life (puppies and kittens get scooped up, but not adults). Getting out for a while would be good for their psyche, surely.
 
 More people should do this. I just don't think people are aware that you can.

there could be one problem:
 
 What about people who are allergic to dogs, cats, or whatever other pet you bring. I'm highly allergic to both dogs and cats and for people living in a nursing home, allergies could be bad.

there could be one problem:
 
 What about people who are allergic to dogs, cats, or whatever other pet you bring. I'm highly allergic to both dogs and cats and for people living in a nursing home, allergies could be bad.

 
 There are potential problems, but I believe that virtually all of them can be resolved using a bit of common sense. In your example, I offer that the staff of the nursing home has the medical records of the residents which would include information concerning allergies, dietary, and other restrictions. Furthermore, I suspect that an individual resident would be aware if they were, in fact, allergic to animal fur. The only potential risk I see is if such an individual has never been in contact with an animal such as a dog or cat, and is allergic. Unlikely. 
 
 You have to see it to believe it. The effect that animals have on the elderly, especially in a nursing home environment, is almost incredible.

 I most definately agree with you that this is a good idea, however...
 
 if they are allergic to them it is likely that even if the pets are in the same building they will have a reaction. I had a really bad reaction from a cat that left some fur in my friend's house the day before (the cat wasn't even there). Of course this would all be known on the records and could be worked out. This sounds like a great idea.
